text.p: Siebel Systems Inc chief financial officer Howard Graham said Thursday he is "optimistic" about the software company's earnings prospects in coming quarters and the growth of the industry as a whole.
Siebel and other high-flying companies in the so-called enterprise application software segment have seen investors pummel their stocks in recent weeks on isolated bad news.
"We're a little concerned that the tone of the market for people in our space is unduly negative," Graham said in an interview.
In a conference call after the earnings were released, Graham and Siebel executives stressed that the company expects strong growth in coming quarters.

"We just wanted to make sure that everybody understood that our view of the market was very very healthy, and that we are quite optimistic for the market as a whole and our company in particular," Graham said.
After the market closed, Siebel said its first-quarter net income rose 14-fold to $2.76 million, or $0.07 a share, from $198,000, or $0.01 a share, in the year-ago quarter.
Wall Street expected Siebel, based in Menlo Park, Calif., to earn $0.04 a share, according to a recent survey by Zacks Investment Research.
First-quarter revenue quadrupled to $19.49 million from $4.71 million.
Siebel writes computer programs that help big corporate sales teams land big contracts.
The company also said Thursday that Compaq Computer Corp purchased Siebel software for 2,200 field and sales representatives. Compaq is now one of the biggest of Siebel's 50 customers, Graham said.
The value of the contract was not disclosed.
